Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Data-Driven Health and Location Monitoring of Livestock
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project are new and innovative products that support sustainable agriculture through precise, automated livestock herd management. Beef cattle is anticipated to be the initial application as beef cattle are largely inspected and managed manually. This is a labor-intensive process and can be prone to mistakes, as lose of tracking of animals in the pastures and rangelands. There is a lack of commercially viable technologies for tracking and monitoring cattle beyond a relatively short range. This innovation directly addresses this shortfall through location tracking and providess health monitoring of individual animals over long distances, enabling beef producers to save management time and labor, avoid losses, maximize herd fertility and nutrition, and sustainably manage rangelands to prevent environmental damage.

This I-Corps project develops a new technology platform that generates high quality, geospatially enabled data with the ability to significantly advance the scientific understanding of livestock productivity and management. This innovation applies recent advances in internet of things (IoT) communications and mobile computing hardware to create a low-power system that collects, analyzes and transmits animal health and location information. This innovation builds upon research that demonstrated the feasibility and design path for the technical approach, and initial animal testing that demonstrated sensor functionality for non-invasive data collection from livestock. The platform has potential to determine biomarkers for early detection of disease, quantify the effect of external stressors on livestock fertility and productivity, enable tools and and procedures for automated/machine-assisted herding, and quantify the ecological benefit of sustainable grazing practices. Sufficiently large datasets will enable advanced algorithms for assessing animal health states.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project executed under NSF Award #1924776 focused on assessing the marketability and commercial opportunity of a GPS-enabled health wearable for beef cattle under development by Roper Solutions, Inc. (fka Reap LLC). We collected data by conducting over 100 interviews with potential customers and partners, and used that data to test hypotheses regarding the value propositions, ideal market segments, and sales channel dynamics.

The first hypothesis we tested was that a major value proposition for our product was the tracking and traceability of individual animals in the food supply chain. However, after interviewing a number of beef retailers, packers and wholesalers, we found that they did not have problems sourcing the quality and quantity of beef needed to conduct their business and meet beef consumer demand. We interviewed both high-end and middle-market establishments, and neither evidenced a need for additional tracking and traceability, indicating there was no value-add that the Roper technology would provide to their links in the supply chain. This finding runs contrary to the notion that increased traceability intrinsically provides increased value to the customer.

Our next line of inquiry focused on the problems and pain-points for beef producers, including cow-calf operators and stocker and backgrounder operations. The hypotheses that we tested focused on the value added from knowing an individual animal’s geographic location and its health state—quite literally, “where’s the beef?”. Our interviews with beef producers showed a willingness to try new methods to improve oversight of their cattle’s location and health as a way to reduce labor and management time, improve veterinary care, and reduce losses due to injury, disease and death. Producers with larger herds (at least 100 cattle) and registered herds both placed higher value on animal location and health information as compared to other types of beef producers. Findings from this line of inquiry indicated that we could find product-market fit with larger operations with registered herds.

In the next part of our project, we explored sales channel dynamics to assess how to best market and sell to beef producers. We tested a number of hypotheses regarding customer perception of animal health products, spending habits, purchasing habits, and decision-making processes. To test these hypotheses, we continued interviewing beef producers, while also interviewing people at multiple levels within animal health companies to understand how animal health products were sourced, distributed, marketed and sold. A major finding was the significant influence that animal health companies and their direct sales forces had in beef producers’ purchasing decisions. This indicated that partnering with animal health companies would streamline the customer acquisition process.

The final part of our project addressed work-flow and location siting considerations that were identified during our interviews with beef producers. This involved the Roper team developing and updating documentation and processes for deploying the Roper technology at individual operations, with the overall objective of improving safety and convenience for both the customer and animal, while ensuring reliable and effective system functionality.

In sum, the work conducted under NSF Award #1924776 provided significant benefit to the team’s entrepreneurial mindset and the ability of Roper Solutions, Inc. to develop a highly compelling business case built around Roper’s proprietary technology.

Broader impacts and intellectual merit of the Roper technology include advancing the scientific understanding of beef production by implementing a new and unique method of near-real-time in situ data collection. This includes the ability to capture unique disease data to aid in the early detection, management and control of livestock diseases, including zoonosis. Additional social and economic impacts include promoting healthy ecologies and preventing catastrophic wildfires through precision and prescribed grazing, and direct support to beginning and disadvantaged beef producers by offsetting lack of experience or resources with evidence-based decision support and grazing plans.
